narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A good oversight of religion and politics and learning how to develop original research (on a small scale) from start to finish. A  good junior class to take before thinking of senior research
I developed a great understanding about the intersectionality of religion and politics in a diverse array of geographic, religious, and political environments.
This course was incredibly helpful in developing my research skills and Dr. Baldwin was a wonderful and encouraging help during this time.
Data analysis, engaging more deeply with research papers (both in evaluating them in the reading responses and in writing the final paper)

I learned a lot about the interaction between religion and politics worldwide. Subjects ranged from religious parties to religion and its relationship with democratization and welfare policy. In addition, for my term paper, I learned how to conduct data-driven research, and present it coherently in writing.

This class is a great way to analyze the ways in which religion affects political behaviors. It covers several topics such as the role o the church, religion and democracy, the economics of religion. I found it very interdisciplinary.
We gained a deeper perspective for the topic, better research tools, and the most phenomenal professor in the world.

Strong foundation in empirical study of religion; some statistical analysis (or at least better understanding of how to interpret statistical analysis); thorough overview of relationships between religious belief, actors, institutions and politics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt as if this was a great course. I really admired how Professor Baldwin was able to navigate a smooth transition to a virtual learning experience. Her students were kept well-engaged, as well, in having to lead discussion and in completing reading responses. There were many strengths of the course... one weakness, however, was that I felt as if some of the readings were too long or there were too many assigned-- such so that I couldn't dedicate the time required to get the most out of them.
I think the course worked well in the seminar format but sometimes the tutorials were challenging because of all the simultaneous feedback to keep track of.

I think a few of the readings were a bit dense at times, but overall this was a great course. Class discussions were interesting and one-on-one breakout rooms with our peers throughout the semester were really helpful in creating a sense of community. The tutorial format was also very helpful for better understanding the research process and engaging with our peers in collaborative work/discussions.

Professor Baldwin, for one, is a definite strength. She is incredibly smart, thoughtful, and approachable during class and in office hours. Professor Baldwin was a particularly helpful for my term paper, as I had never completed a true data-driven research paper. The term paper was super flexible and I liked the data requirement. Class discussions were great too, especially during tutorials. I'm not sure if Professor Baldwin intends to continue tutorials after the coronavirus, but I really liked them, as they allowed students to get direct feedback on their work, and also grow closer with classmates. No weaknesses.

The material is engaging. Having to lead discussion some weeks and having to write a paper on others means that you end up understanding a lot of the material covered since you study much of it in detail. It also means that it can be a lot of work since you will likely have something due every week.  Professor Baldwin is very understanding and encouraging though, and she recognizes the work that you put into the class.  The class could benefit from more modern examples/research.

Professor Baldwin is genuinely the most thoughtful professor that I have ever had -- this course genuinely did not have weaknesses because she worked so hard to keep us engaged, to be fair, and to keep things interesting.

Strengths: great instructor and facilitation; good overview of diverse political and religious environments, with emphasis on Christianity and Islam; good mix of technical and accessible readings

Could be improved by including more in-country readings or analysis from within religious traditions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: second session of the week was 35 mins long and only had half the class in it to give more personalised experience and exposure
I felt as if this class was conducted as well as it could have been! Professor Baldwin was awesome at providing help when needed. She was very understanding to her students' circumstances.
I honestly think the virtual format of this class was ideal.
As mentioned in my response above, the tutorial format and small group breakout rooms were really helpful.

If tutorials were structured specifically for covid-19 (or not) I found them to be particularly effectual in shaping class discussion and dynamics. Professor Baldwin used breakout room chats at the beginning of class, which were very effective in building a close-knit class community. No improvements I can think of.

Professor Baldwin had us to check-ins just to see how each other are/to make sure we got to know each other, had tutorial groups, and used all the functionalities that the digital world has in order to empower this course.
Zoom breakout rooms were effective for discussion

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. A great intro to religion and politics and very well adapted to online learning

Yes, I would. Although I would caution them that it is heavy on reading. Also, because of the small size of the class occupancy, that students must be comfortable speaking and sharing their thoughts to a group.
Yes, the professor is wonderful and it gives helpful information and discussion to understand the importance of religion in political life through a number of different lenses.
Yes! Professor Baldwin is great and we learned a lot about crafting research papers, engaging with the material more deeply and critically, and it provided a great environment for learning.
Yes! Super interesting topic and very cool and flexible term paper. Professor Baldwin leads great discussions and is incredibly caring.
Yes. Professor Baldwin is great, and the content is interesting.
ABSOLUTELY! Professor Baldwin is EXCEPTIONAL. I am LUCKY to have learned from her -- and encourage EVERYONE to take the chance to do so.
Would highly recommend to other students, graduate or undergraduate.
